docs.lead_paragraph: It is more a rebellion than a strike. The walkout by 185,000 drivers, loaders and sorters of the United Parcel Service is best seen as the angry, fist-waving response of the frustrated American worker, a revolt against the ruthless treatment of workers by so many powerful corporations. The Times's Dirk Johnson quoted a U.P.S. employee, Laura Pisciotti, on the picket line in Willow Springs, Ill.: ''These companies all have the formula. They don't take you on full time. They don't pay benefits. Then their profits go through the roof.''
docs.abstract: Bob Herbert Op-Ed column on teamster's strike against United Parcel Service; scores company's abuse of part-time workers (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The 40-year-old entrepreneur who built Oxford Health Plans into a $4 billion giant of managed health care in metropolitan New York resigned yesterday as chief executive. The executive, Steven F. Wiggins, will remain as chairman. He said yesterday that his successor, William Sullivan, 34, a longtime Oxford executive, ''is better than me at most of the day-to-day things that involve being the C.E.O. of a company.''

headline.main: Oxford Founder Resigns Job; Company Posts Large Profits

docs.abstract: Steven F Wiggins, 40-year-old entrepreneur who built Oxford Health Plans into $4 billion giant of managed health care in metropolitan New York, resigns as chief executive; says he will remain as chairman; names William Sullivan, age 34, as his successor, saying he 'is better than me at most of the day-to-day things that involve being the C.E.O. of a company'; shares of Oxford decline $3.6875, to $82.175; Oxford reports that earnings rose 65.5 percent, to $37.18 million, on revenue of $1.06 billion in three months ending June 30; Wiggins also says Oxford has made improvements in its late billing problems; earnings chart (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: COULD the incredibly rapid rise in cases of melanoma be caused by an overdiagnosis of malignant lesions that, if left alone, would never grow to threaten life? That is what two dermatologists from Emory University in Atlanta say may largely account for the fact that 1 in 84 Americans is now expected to develop melanoma, up from 1 in 250 less than two decades ago and 1 in 1,500 in 1935. But others argue that the increase in melanomas is all too real.

headline.main: Focus Is on Diagnosis As Melanoma Rates Soar

docs.abstract: Dermatologists at Emory University report that rapid rise in cases of melanoma may be caused by an overdiagnosis of malignant lesions that, if left alone, would never grow to threaten life; other dermatologists say that it is only prudent to remove even small lesions and that increased surveillance for skin cancers cannot explain rise in number of melanoma deaths; if Emory researchers are right, it would mean that scarce medical resources are being squandered on unnecessary and sometimes disfiguring surgery to remove lesions that are unlikely to grow and spread; people diagnosed with melanoma also have an extremely hard time obtaining health insurance; graph (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: With Speaker Newt Gingrich by his side, President Clinton today signed two bills he called a ''true milestone for our nation'' that put into place a plan to balance the Federal budget and to cut taxes for the first time since the Reagan era. The signing ceremony on the South Lawn of the White House marked a truce between the Republicans and Democrats after two and a half years of partisan struggle on fiscal issues that led to the acrimonious Government shutdowns and veto fights of 1995. American flags dotted the lawn. A Marine band on the White House balcony played ''God Bless America.''
docs.abstract: Pres Clinton, accompanied by Speaker Newt Gingrich, signs bills to balance budget by 2002 and cut taxes by net of $95 billion over five years; Clinton, Gingrich and Vice Pres Al Gore hail bills; Rep Richard A Gephardt, who is expected to challenge Gore for 2000 Presidential nomination and opposed budget accord, is notably absent; photo (M)
docs.snippet: With Speaker Newt Gingrich by his side, President Clinton today signed two bills he called a ''true milestone for our nation'' that put into place a plan to balance the Federal budget and to cut taxes for the first time since the Reagan era.    The...

docs.lead_paragraph: Alongside large tax cuts with mass appeal, like reductions in property taxes and the sales tax on clothing, New York's new state budget is sprinkled with smaller cuts tailored for particular industries, some reflecting the lobbying of particular companies like International Business Machines and the Ringling Brothers and Barnum & Bailey Circus. Ringling and its lobbyists, the influential firm of Davidoff & Malito, won the elimination of the state sales tax on circus tickets, a cut that will cost the state a mere $100,000 a year. Because other major circuses, like the Big Apple Circus, are already exempt as ''teaching circuses,'' only Ringling and perhaps one or two others that pass through the state each year were paying the tax, and only they will benefit from its elimination.

headline.main: Budget Offers Cornucopia of Tax Breaks For Everyone

docs.abstract: Tax-cut provisions in New York State's new budget package discussed; alongside large reductions having mass appeal, it is sprinkled with smaller cuts tailored for particular industries (M)
docs.snippet: Alongside large tax cuts with mass appeal, like reductions in property taxes and the sales tax on clothing, New York's new state budget is sprinkled with smaller cuts tailored for particular industries, some reflecting the lobbying of particular...

docs.lead_paragraph: Shares of Aetna tumbled more than 12 percent yesterday after the company, one of the nation's largest managed health care concerns, said that costs were rising faster than premiums, especially in its Medicare health maintenance organizations. Shares of Aetna fell $14.25, to $102.75, on the New York Stock Exchange, where the stock was one of the most heavily traded. The opening of trading in Aetna shares was delayed for nearly two hours. Shares of other H.M.O. companies were also lower.

headline.main: Aetna Stock Plunges 12% On Cost News

docs.abstract: Shares of Aetna Life and Casualty decline more than 12 percent after company, one of the nation's largest managed health care concerns, says costs are rising faster than premiums, especially in its Medicare health maintenance organizations; rising costs and company's lowered projections for growth this year reflect intensifying competition among HMO's as Aetna has reconfigured itself into managed health care company; Moody's Investors Service analyst says outlook for rising medical costs and more intense competition on prices threatens to squeeze Aetna's profit margins; HMO companies in many cities have been competing for Government dollars by offering generous benefits to elderly persons, seeking market share at expense of profits (M)
docs.snippet: Shares of Aetna tumbled more than 12 percent yesterday after the company, one of the nation's largest managed health care concerns, said that costs were rising faster than premiums, especially in its Medicare health maintenance organizations.   ...

docs.lead_paragraph: The New York State Legislature has approved a last-minute state budget item permitting thousands of New York City's most experienced teachers to retire early, a measure that runs counter to a legislative initiative announced with fanfare last week -- one that would reduce class size by hiring more teachers. The retirement measure, which is opposed by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew, still needs approval by Gov. George E. Pataki, and both City Hall and the city's Board of Education said they would lobby hard against it. A spokesman for the Governor said Mr. Pataki had not yet decided how he would act.

headline.main: MEASURE TO ALLOW EARLY RETIREMENT BY CITY TEACHERS

docs.abstract: New York State Legislature approves last-minute budget item to let New York City teachers retire with full pension at age 55 after as few as 10 years on job; Mayor Rudolph W Giuliani and Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew oppose measure and will press Gov George E Pataki to veto it; bill, approved despite state plan to cut class size by hiring more teachers, shows extraordinary influence of United Federation of Teachers; UFT president, Sandra Feldman, lobbied furiously for bill, catching city and Education Board largely off guard (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: An Aug. 1 news article reports that lack of health insurance is driving many working poor people into bankruptcy. A similarly affected group is the disabled chronically ill. Considered disabled for purposes of Social Security, they are eligible for Medicare, which does not cover prescription medicine, usually the treatment of choice. They must therefore spend thousands of dollars a year out of their own pockets for medication.

headline.kicker: When Death Is Near, Only Honesty Will Do

docs.abstract: Kevin Twine letter deplores the health insurance bind of the disabled chronically ill (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: It's too bad that our economic prosperity is clouded by messy realities like the uninsured working poor (news article, Aug. 1).

headline.kicker: When Death Is Near, Only Honesty Will Do

docs.lead_paragraph: It was 7:45 A.M. when Eddie Breedlove, speechless and grasping a swollen jaw, signed the log at the St. Vincent Health Clinic East here. He had roused his wife and their three small children at 5 to make the 50-mile drive from their home in a rattling 16-year-old Mercury, after weeks in which he had been tormented by a relentless toothache. ''He said that last night he drank as much as he could,'' an aide recounted, having interviewed him, ''and then used a pocketknife to try to get it out.''
docs.abstract: Americans without health insurance are for the most part working people who cling to bottom rung of the ladder but who frequently do not qualify for the health care assistance available to the unemployed poor; Census Bureau reports 41 million Americans, or about 15.4 percent of all Americans, lacked health care insurance throughout 1995; among those below Federal poverty line, proportion was 30.2 percent; doctors note a greater incidence of physical and mental disorders among the uninsured; photo (M)
